description: From Middle English sheth, shethe (“holder for a sword, knife, etc., scabbard, sheath”) [and other forms], from Old English sċēaþ (“sheath”), from Proto-West Germanic *skaiþiju, from Proto-Germanic *skaiþiz (“sheath; covering”), from Proto-Indo-European *skey- (“to dissect, split”) (possibly from the notion of a split stick with a sword inserted).
The English word is cognate with Danish skede, Dutch schede, Icelandic skeið, German Scheide, Low German scheed, Norwegian skjede.

entries.meaning: A holster for a sword; a scabbard.
(by extension) Anything that has a similar shape to a scabbard that is used to hold an object that is longer than it is wide.
examples: Synonyms: case, casing, cover, covering, envelope

entries.meaning: (botany) The base of a leaf when sheathing or investing a branch or stem, as in grasses.
(electrical engineering) The insulating outer cover of an electrical cable.
(entomology) One of the elytra of an insect.
(zoology) The foreskin of certain animals (for example, dogs and horses).

verbs.description: sheath (third-person singular simple present sheaths, present participle sheathing, simple past and past participle sheathed)
